wind's coming from here.

We're actually out of
beam reach right now.

- We've got no wind instruments
and a squall came past

and I was like I don't know
where the wind's coming from.
(gentle guitars)
- Elayna, you going down wind?
Whoo!

♪ For 16 years I've been
in self-destruct mode ♪

♪ Just waiting for that
timer to run out on me ♪
(gentle guitar)

- [Elayna] Here on the
Vagabond last Monday,

myself, Riley, and Stefan
from Germany, whom we love

and we wanna keep forever,
pulled out the Code D
for a speedy ride up to Sombrero Island.
Here we are, Sombrero.
Oh my gosh.
(bird screeches)
Sombrero Island, seriously, what a spot.

- [Riley] That was a pretty
nice breaky burrito, parents.
- You're very welcome.
- [Riley] This is the weather, which
I've downloaded last night.

If we leave at 4 p.m. this
afternoon, it's good, good, good,

then there's a bit of a dead
patch, so we don't wanna

be caught out in this
area here, cause it's just
a little bit dead.

And you can see the wind
swings north a bit, that's when
we wanna jibe south.
Then there's dead patches there again.

As you can see there, there's
even more larger dead patches

over here, and getting
bigger before we lob
into the Dominican Republic over here.

All we have to do is have
a swim before we leave.
- And you wanna go spear fishing?
- [Riley] Yes, I do.
(electronic music)

Trying to get right over the
top of that because we're in

20 metres of water, just
to keep the white off her.
(melancholy music)

We had a three to four
day sail ahead of us.
Roughly 480 nautical miles northwest.

I was looking forward to
doing a bit of a longer one.
Time to reset.
I just did some gym work this morning.
I woke up feeling absolutely buckled.

It's funny when you're sailing,
it's good sometimes when

a squall comes and you have
to make a quick sail change

or something like that cause
you can get pretty tired.

Cause just getting up and
moving around and doing stuff,

you just get the lethargy that
can settle in if it's tame,
which is pretty common.

So the wind, I guess it's
blowing 15-18, from about

120 degrees, but when we turned
on navigation this morning,

there's clearly some sort
of technical problem because

it's saying that it's
coming from 180 degrees,
but it said that the whole time.

It said that it's roughly
seven knots of true wind

when it's definitely not.
- It's totally off.

I'm sure it's nothing wrong
with the actual hardware

or connections or anything,
it's just gonna be some buttons

that I don't know what
to press in what order.

I got on the sat finder, and
it just means that if you don't

know exactly what the
apparent wind speed is,

you're gonna be less
likely to run the Code D.

You might go, oh, it's only
eight knots instead of 12,

but we've gotta get to
the Dominican Republic

to drop Stefan off before we
get to Caicos to meet dad.

I would've loved to
hang around in Sombrero

for even longer, but that's
the situation at the moment.
How you going, boo town?

- Good, I'm gonna listen
to a podcast and I feel
really good today.
After that swim, it really wakes you up.
That was a really cool place to go.

That was Riley's idea
to take us to Sombrero.

That was epic, that's one
of the things I'll remember
for a very long time.

Like I explained, when
we were on the island,
I never had a feeling like that.

You know how you get a
different feeling each place

you travel, and when you
think about it that's how
you kind of remember it.
Those same feelings come up.

I've just never had that
combination of feelings before.
- [Riley] Not me either.
It's a very unique place.
- It is.

- Elayna and I have laughed,
because in the past we've been

to a place and I'm like
this is the best place ever.
Then I'll start looking at real estate.
- (laughing) But then we just move on
and that's the best place.
- Yeah.

- I don't think there
is a best place ever.
I haven't found it.
Have you?
- (mumbles)
(waves crashing)

I'm just mucking around,
cause I did the factory reset

on this chart, but I'm just
gonna change everything back.
I wanna know how to move forward.
And I have to shave my beard as well.
- It's family time.
We're been ignoring each other all day,
but we've come together for dinner.

- What podcast have you
been listening to, Elayna?

- The Your Own Magic
podcast, for Kel and Ally.
- Stefan, what have you been listening to?
- [Stefan] I have an audiobook,
but I couldn't really follow.
Most of the time I was napping.
- Yeah, you did sleep a fair bit today.
I hope you sleep tonight.
- [Stefan] Yeah, I think I'm fine.
(waves lapping)

- I've just gone to wash the
dishes and the water is brown.
So yeah, the water is brown.
What's wrong with the water?
- I have no idea.
I thought that maybe it was very low,

and that might be in
the bottom of the tank,
but that's not the case.
- [Elayna] That's very weird.
- Run it a bit and see how much comes out.
- [Elayna] I just ran it for awhile,
and it's clear again, yeah.

Riley's not concerned, so I
guess I'm not concerned either.
- Tips for young cruisers.
If you've had a shower, it's gonna be
pretty humid in there.

Get straight out on deck
and dry off in the wind.
You'll save your towels, you won't have
to wash them as often.
- [Elayna] Your pores

will close faster.
- And it's way better,
isn't it, Elayna?
Your pores close.

- [Elayna] I'm sure most
people would already
do this, wouldn't they?

- Well, when I found out
about it, it was a revelation.

- [Elayna] It is really
nice drying outside.

- We've just narrowly
avoided the Genco Challenger.

me to look at the arrow?

Feels like you're going
a bit too far downwind.
Babe, the wind's coming from here.
- [Riley] Where?

- [Elayna] Uh, you're actually
out of beam reach right now.
You're fine, keep on this course.

Well, we just got the
back end of a squall,
and we were flying for a second there.

It was like all hands
on deck, but we're gonna

take in the Code D now
anyway cause it's like

I don't even know what time,
and yeah, we should relax
for the rest of the night (laughs).

We're clipping in Stefan, he's
going up front to wind it in.
- [Riley] All right, go on, mate.
- [Stefan] Like that?
- [Riley] Yep, man, beautiful.
- [Stefan] Nice.
- [Elayna] How ya feeling?
- Pretty tired.
It's about 4 o'clock.

We've got no wind instruments
and a squall came past,

and I just lost where the
wind was, and I was like

I don't know where the wind's
coming from (laughing),

cause it felt like it was
coming from in front of us

and it was, which meant
that I'd gone into it,

which would have put so much
pressure on that Code D.
I was disorientated.

- [Elayna] But we wound
out the head sail now,
and now we're safe.
We don't need to think about it.

The best thing about eating
oats at 4 o'clock in the morning
has probably got to be eating oats
at 4 o'clock in the morning.

There's just nothing like
it, it's just so comforting,

oh did I mention there was
peanut butter in there as well?
You just can't go wrong with oats.
Morning, everyone.
It's about 8 o'clock, day two of our trip
to Dominican Republic.

This morning, Stefan and
I rolled out the Code D

cause the winds died off
again, and Riley just woke up.

He's making a list at the
moment, which he wants
me to join him on.
A boat list of some kind.
I best get to it.
Alright, so what have you come up with?

- These are all jobs that
we think will be easier
to do off the east coast of the U.S.

I'm actually, some of
these are gonna be great.
Speargun rack in port forward locker,

I wanna get a spinnaker,
like a cruising spinnaker.

Braid all the equipment
and hold it at the back

made out of grey or black
netting that sits just on top

of the davidon so we
can just throw wet suits

and fins and stuff and
it's easily accessible.

Filleting table, where the
parasail would slide in

at the back, so I could
sort of slide it in,

sit there like held in place,
do my filleting with one end

open so the stuff just
slid out into the ocean.

I need to get the propellers
for the (mumbles).
They're both still broken.
Iridium antenna needs to go up the mast
and come out here so that we can.

- [Elayna] Yeah, if you guys
remember on the Atlantic

crossing, we had it through
this window, and every time
it rained it would all go on my stove.
We need to instal that properly.

- We're considering getting
rid of the outside table,

just for freedom of
movement, and we don't mind
eating food off our laps.

- A collapsible one.
- [Elayna] Yeah, yeah.
- That could be a great idea.

- [Elayna] Yeah, I
reckon we should do that.
- But we're just thinking about that now.
- Riley's just changing out the big lures.

We're just gonna stick
with the little lures today
and hopefully we get a nice-sized dorado

If it's a smaller fish,
we'll still be able to keep

sailing and winding and
hopefully we'll still have
the fish on the end of the line.

- Are you going downwind?
Whoo!

- Well there you go, we got
a mahi-mahi just like that.
Amazing.
- Beautiful fish.
It's already changing colour though.

Alright, there's yours.

- Yeah.

It's amazing.

Like we've been saying, the

We're very much looking
